assessment.title: Resistance Assessment
assessment.description: The IT department is showing strong resistance to the new ERP system. They claim it's too complex and will slow down operations. How do you respond?

choices.text: Organize a detailed training session with IT leadership
Implement the system gradually with IT input

planning.title: Timeline Pressure
planning.description: The board wants to accelerate the timeline by 2 months to meet quarterly targets. This would require cutting some training time. What's your decision?

choices.text: Negotiate for additional resources to maintain quality
Accept the timeline but extend training post-launch

communication.title: Communication Crisis
communication.description: Rumors are spreading that the new system will lead to job cuts. Employee morale is plummeting. How do you address this?

choices.text: Hold an all-hands meeting to address concerns transparently
Send detailed email communications about job security
Focus on technical training and ignore the rumors

engagement.title: Key Champion Leaves
engagement.description: Your main change champion from the operations team has resigned. This was a critical supporter who was driving adoption. How do you respond?

choices.text: Quickly identify and train a new champion
Distribute champion responsibilities across multiple people

monitoring.title: Performance Metrics
monitoring.description: Adoption rates are below target, but the system is working well for those using it. The board is questioning the investment. What's your strategy?

choices.text: Implement additional incentives and recognition programs
Focus on demonstrating ROI to the board
Make system usage mandatory with consequences
